1.text:
• From wars in the Middle East to faulty
computer chips simulating a real nuclear attack,

6.text:
we count 15 times the world almost came to
an end in our age of nuclear weapons

11.text:
15 - 1979 NORAD computer glitch
• This occurred on the morning of November

17.text:
9th, 1979 at Colorado's North American Aerospace
Defence Command

22.text:
• Technicians received reports that the
Soviets had launched a series of missiles

28.text:
at North America, with the response being
to launch 10 interceptor fighter planes, get

33.text:
the president on an escape plane and prepare
to launch a retaliatory strike

38.text:
• Then we find out a technician had accidentally
started a training program to simulate a Soviet

44.text:
attack, a computer glitch that almost destroyed
everyone on Earth

49.text:
14 - Attack on Yeonpyeong
• This took place not too long ago, November

54.text:
2010, an attack by North Korea against South
Korean troops stationed at the island of Yeonpyeong

60.text:
• They launched a total of 160 missiles
against them, decimating a huge number of

65.text:
people - and even worse, inciting the possibility
this border conflict might escalate in World

70.text:
War 3
• Though we've so far avoided it, this event

74.text:
is still a tragic, meaningless waste of human
life

77.text:
13 - B-52 Crash near Thule
• January 21st, 1968, a fire breaks out

84.text:
on a B-52 bomber - the pilot has not time
to contact base before he bales out

90.text:
• The plane crashes in some ice 7 miles
offshore of Thule, then its fuel and certain

94.text:
compounds of nuclear weapons explode, but
does NOT trigger a nuclear detonation

100.text:
• If it had, alerts would have shown an
attack on both the nearby base and the bomber

105.text:
itself - indicating to the White House an
enemy attack and need for immediate retaliation,

109.text:
but luckily none of this came to pass
12 - 1995 Research Rocket

116.text:
• Norway, January of 1995, local scientists
launch a research rocket to study the aurora

121.text:
borealis
• Meanwhile, in Russia, eyes boggle as what

125.text:
looks like a gigantic nuclear warhead torpedoes
towards them - so President Boris Yeltsin

131.text:
whips out his briefcase full of nuclear codes
purely to launch nukes at every target they

136.text:
can reach
• Thankfully, the missile fell into the

138.text:
ocean, Yeltsin put away his briefcase and
instead picked up a delicious sandwich

143.text:
11 - Soviet Early Warning False Alarm
• September 26th, 1983, a secret bunker

150.text:
owned by the Soviets - commander Stanislav
Petrov has just settled into a chair when

155.text:
a loud siren went off and screens showed that
Americans had launched 5 missiles

160.text:
• They only had minutes to respond, there
was chaos and stress in the bunker, because

164.text:
of the enormous incoming payload, the chain
of command went straight to Petrov and he

169.text:
had to decide if he wanted to respond with
missiles, or call in a false alarm

173.text:
• He decided to do the latter, but not because
they realised they were fakes, no, because

178.text:
he knew his equipment was new and he wasn't
prepared to begin World War 3 based on computer

183.text:
data alone - but he said he really did believe
missiles were on their way, which made it

188.text:
damn near impossible to call them fakes, but
he did and we're all thankful for his call

196.text:
• This is another training program like
the NORAD computer glitch, but much more elaborate

200.text:
and very nearly took us to war by accident
• It was an exercise called Able Archer

205.text:
83, in which an attack on Europe would be
met with a U.S military strike on the Soviets

209.text:
• The U.S airlifted 19,000 troops to Europe
and changed alert status to DEFCON 1, and

216.text:
meanwhile, though the Soviets knew it was
just a war game, they too went into high alert

222.text:
and prepared their nukes - both poised to
attack at the drop of a feather, but luckily

226.text:
the games ended not long after and things
calmed down

230.text:
9 - 9/11
• One of the most tragic events in modern

234.text:
history, the Twin Towers - those iconic structures
from New York City were hit by two airplanes

239.text:
on September 11th, 2001
• Likewise, another plane crashed into the

243.text:
Pentagon and one more near the White House
on the same day, perpetrated by Osama Bin

248.text:
Laden and the terrorist group Al Queda
• Over 3,000 people died that day, and it

253.text:
began the war on terror which could have quickly
escalated into a bomb-filled conflict

257.text:
• Nuclear terrorism is the next step up,
but thankfully countries around the world

263.text:
are taking measures to prevent this
8 - Middle East False Alarm

267.text:
• 1973, the U.S sponsored a cease fire to
end the Arab-Isreali war, but further fighting

273.text:
began between Egyptian and Israeli troops
in the Sinai desert

277.text:
• Since Nixon was involved in the Watergate
scandal, several U.S officials took it upon

282.text:
themselves to enter DEFCON 3 to warn the U.S.S.R
not to intervene with the events in Sinai

287.text:
• This was all fine, except a Klaxon accidentally
went off at Kinchole Air Force Base in Michigan,

294.text:
which you DON'T want during DEFCON 3 - this
set off the entire base and almost had B-52

300.text:
bombers take off, but luckily the alarm was
fixed and nothing happened

305.text:
7 - War in Afghanistan
• Here we find a 9 year conflict - an attack

309.text:
by two world powers against each other without
using nukes, instead, by having the U.S and

315.text:
UK finance and arm Afghan-Mujahideens to fight
the local Soviets - a proxy war, you might

321.text:
say, hiding behind foreign troops to further
your own agendas

325.text:
• It was such a sickening move that Jimmy
Carter was quoted as saying that it was the

329.text:
most significant threat to world peace since
WW2, two enemies involving an overseas body

334.text:
shield between their own personal conflicts
with the result - escalation and destruction

339.text:
6 - Faulty Computer Chip
• June 3rd, 1980, a simple number algorithm

345.text:
showing whether nukes were on their way and
how many, where it should have read 0000,

351.text:
it read 2222 - and though the number was insanely
high, it was still possible and nuclear bomber

358.text:
crews started their engine waiting for the
go-ahead

360.text:
• It was discovered to be a false alarm
and things were fine, but once again 3 days

365.text:
later the same thing happened, 2222 bombs
on their way, the nuclear bomber crews still

370.text:
had their engines revved from earlier in the
week

373.text:
• But the problem was basic - a computer
chip displayed 0s as 2s, but even so, all

379.text:
it takes is one bad computer chip to wipe
out the human race

382.text:
5 - Cuban Missile Crisis
• The rest of the items in this list will

387.text:
relate to this crisis spanning 13 terrifying
days in 1962

393.text:
• Missile silos were stationed in Cuba and
boats shipped even more nukes, but U.S President

400.text:
Kennedy formed a blockade to stop more boats
from arriving

403.text:
• The Soviets took this as an act of aggression
and I quote "one that propels human kind into

409.text:
the abyss of a world nuclear-missile war"
• 13 days passed in which U.S Navy boats

415.text:
were told to open fire on any encroaching
ships

419.text:
• Then Kennedy made a deal with Soviet Premier
Khrushchev to dismantle their warheads in

425.text:
Turkey, as well as agree never to invade Cuba,
and in exchange the Soviets would remove all

430.text:
their weapons from Cuba
• It is the closest human kind has ever

433.text:
come to engaging in all-out nuclear war
4 - An Animal Nearly Starts World War 3

440.text:
• During the same period in the missile
crisis, alarms went up in a Duluth American

445.text:
air base indicating an intruder and possibly
Soviet bombers overhead

449.text:
• Pilots scrambled around, already tense
from the most chaotic time in history - but

454.text:
it was a false alarm, one that nearly destroyed
us all - and it was caused by a bear

460.text:
• That's right, a damn bear somehow snuck
into the base and set off alarms, almost killing

466.text:
every man, woman and child on this planet
3 - Moorestown False Alarm

471.text:
• October 28th, a town in New Jersey reported
that a nuclear attack was underway - when

476.text:
in reality it was a test tape simulating a
Cuban missile attack, but coincidentally a

481.text:
satellite happened to pass over the area at
that exact moment which, when combined with

486.text:
the stress from those 13 days, leads to a
recipe for assumptions

490.text:
• The entirety of NORAD was informed and
put on alert, but before a counter-attack

495.text:
could take place, the expected time on the
Moorestown explosion did NOT take place

500.text:
• The radar system responsible for confirming
an incoming missile was not in operation that

504.text:
day because personnel had been reassigned
for the Crisis

508.text:
2 - U-2 Spy Plane
• One day before the Cuban Missile Crisis

513.text:
ended, an American spy plane got lost because
the aurora borealis obscured his vision of

518.text:
the stars used for navigation
• He drifted off course and ended up in

523.text:
the airspace of the Soviet Union
• This simple miscalculation caused a dramatic

528.text:
response from both sides - the Soviets scrambled
fighter jets to intercept and destroy the

534.text:
plane, while the Americans sent nuclear-armed
fighters in response to escort the plane back

538.text:
to American soil, which they did just barely
before the Soviet jets arrived

543.text:
• Had either side engaged in aerial warfare
- it would've been a disaster

548.text:
1 - B-59 Submarine
• That same day begins my favourite story

554.text:
from the era, one that shows how one man can
save or destroy the entire planet

560.text:
• This Soviet B-59 submarine was holding
underwater near the U.S blockade line near

565.text:
Cuba when an American ship began dropping
warning shots to force them to resurface

570.text:
• The submarine officers took this as real,
legitimate fire to mark the beginning of World

575.text:
War 3, and the captain ordered a nuclear missile
for launch

578.text:
• Had he alone been given authority to launch,
a nuclear war would've begun, but luckily

584.text:
he needed two senior officers to give their
okay and one of them didn't, Vasili Arkhipov,

590.text:
who convinced them to resurface and request
new orders from Moscow

594.text:
• This man, Vasili Arkhipov, saved the world
and it would be another 40 years before people
